image.altText: Roia Atmar holds a framed photo of her three  young children

props.synopsis: Mother-of-four Roia Atmar says that her husband burned her in a bid to disfigure her so "nobody else would look at me". Researchers say domestic burns violence cases like hers are often under-reported for reasons including fear and shame.

title.children: Reported DV fire incidents 'tip of the iceberg', researcher says

image.altText: Visitors walk towards Dingley Dell, a white heritage cottage surrounded by greenery, with signage visible in the foreground

props.synopsis: A former dot-com millionaire's plan to install glamping tents at Adam Lindsay Gordon's cottage is opposed by fans of the 19th-century poet.

title.children: Fans of 19th-century poet fight former tech millionaire's glamping bid

image.altText: An elderly man in a jumper smiles for a family photo

props.synopsis: A coroner recommends transport authorities better utilise their discretion to suspend the licences of at-risk drivers, following the death of an 86-year-old on South Australia's Karoonda Highway in 2019.

title.children: Death of elderly driver in SA highway crash prompts push for change

image.altText: SA Water

props.synopsis: Developers and SA Water cannot agree on how to divvy up the cost of new pipes, leaving the future of more than 1,000 homes outside Adelaide shrouded in uncertainty.

title.children: More than 1,000 homes in limbo as SA Water money dries up

image.altText: A man standing in front of his green car.

props.synopsis: Tyler Redway got a licence after passing driving tests in his own vehicle modified to his needs. But there are concerns that, under new rules, people like him will no longer be able to do that.

title.children: Change to obtaining SA drivers licences set to impact people with disability

image.altText: One Nation MP Sarah Game with party leader Pauline Hanson.

props.synopsis: One Nation is no stranger to internal rumblings, and its latest imbroglio has occurred in South Australia, where state upper house MP Sarah Game recently announced her decision to quit the party and become an independent.

title.children: One Nation styles itself as a party of unity, but has been beset by defection

image.altText: Torrens Island power station

props.synopsis: SafeWork SA has lodged criminal proceedings against energy giant AGL alleging the company exposed workers to "unsafe levels of lead" at its Torrens Island plant.

title.children: Charges laid against AGL over 'unsafe' lead exposure

image.altText: A woman smiles with a medal.

props.synopsis: In the letter to his wife, Rohan Dennis says he is "so sorry for what happened" and that she will "forever be the glue that holds us together".

title.children: Rohan Dennis apologises to wife Melissa Hoskins in letter written after her death

image.altText: A boxer in black gloves and a boxer with white gloves exchange jabs to the head.

props.synopsis: Knockouts are the aim of the game, but competitive boxers are looking to minimise head trauma as knowledge of its impact grows.

title.children: As interest in combat sport grows, athletes look to protect their heads

image.altText: Sexyland Exterior

props.synopsis: Workers at adult store chain Sexyland say they are harassed and threatened by customers on an almost nightly basis, with the stores lacking reporting systems to monitor abuse.

title.children: Sexyland workers allege 'disgusting and traumatic' harassment and sales

image.altText: A man wearing a black shirt leaning next to a meat smoker.

props.synopsis: Backyard chefs such as Callan Buchholz are brushing up on their low and slow barbecue skills, with the American-style trend of meat smoking feeding the whole tribe.

title.children: American-style meat smoking puts a new spin on the Aussie Sunday roast

image.altText: A bulldozer moves black material at a processing facility surrounded by conveyors, large buildings, and chimneys.

props.synopsis: One of the biggest industrial manufacturing employers in Tasmania's north says a lack of ore supply and US tariffs have played a part in a decision to pause smelter operations.

title.children: Trump tariffs, ore price cited as Tasmanian smelter announces 'limited operations'

image.altText: Donald Trump stands at a podium and points straight ahead.

props.synopsis: Vladimir Putin was trained in the KGB world of working out the psychology of your opponent, so it is not surprising he is outfoxing Donald Trump. The US president is now talking about walking away from peace talks.

title.children: Played by Putin, a 'weary' Trump could walk away from Ukraine

image.altText: Peter Malinauskas speaks to the media.

props.synopsis: An 18-year-old man was last week arrested and accused of threatening violent attacks on an SA school and public events, following what the premier described as the "probably the most complex and significant case" he had been briefed on. Here's a look at what we know.

title.children: What we know about alleged violent threats on SA school and events

image.altText: Nevill Westwood stands aside Bubsie, wearing overalls and a hat. The image is black and white.

props.synopsis: A 102-year-old restored Citroën will retrace the first circumnavigation of Australia exactly a century after the feat was achieved by the same model.

title.children: Century-old car brought back to life to retrace 1925 circumnavigation

image.altText: an outside view of a row of houses

props.synopsis: Many hoped that interest rate cuts could make housing more affordable. But cheaper money for housing, amid a market with high demand and low supply, will keep fuelling property prices.

title.children: 'Impossibly unaffordable': Why property prices in Australia will keep rising

image.altText: Anthony Albanese Xi Jinping composite

props.synopsis: The trip follows a warm letter of congratulations from China's leader following Anthony Albanese's election win.

title.children: Second China visit for Albanese as Xi seeks closer Australia ties

image.altText: Poster saying 'Wanted by the FBI' with name and mugshot image of Australian man Geoffrey John Busch

props.synopsis: Geoffrey John Busch is wanted over an investment scam in Florida in the early 2000s and just months after a renewed FBI effort to track him down, the ABC found him living in Sydney's southern suburbs.

title.children: Man wanted by FBI found 'living in a family environment' in Sydney

image.altText: A young woman holding out bowls of food to her four children next to some camps at a refugee camp.

props.synopsis: Humanitarian organisations warn current aid levels are not enough to tackle the hunger crisis gripping Gaza, as the British government suspends trade talks with Israel over its expanded military offensive in the strip.

title.children: UN issues warning as Gazan babies face food shortages

image.altText: Young girl Camille in bed showing her arms which have wound plasters on her arms.

props.synopsis: Experts say it is the worst year for the soil-born disease in Queensland in around three decades. Meet those who've survived the deadly disease and learn more about what to look out for.

title.children: Three months and 50 tests later, 11yo discovers what made her sick 'by chance'

image.altText: Daniel Mookhey

props.synopsis: With dissent mounting, tensions are set to escalate within caucus and close stakeholders, including the unions.

title.children: NSW workers comp changes dubbed a 'bandaid solution'

image.altText: David Littleproud speaks at a press conference.

props.synopsis: Queensland's Liberal National Party says it is "optimistic" an agreement will be reached between the two federal parties in the future.

title.children: Coalition split unlikely to impact Queensland's LNP

image.altText: Close-up of a white marble statue of a woman with folded hands, carved into a temple pillar

props.synopsis: A community of 750 first-generation migrants has spent a decade fasting daily and raising millions to construct Victoria's first Jain temple, using special methods to honour ancient traditions while meeting modern building codes.

title.children: After a decade of fasting and fundraising a Jain temple takes shape

image.altText: A screengrab of George Wendt sitting at a bar and holding a peanut.

props.synopsis: George Wendt, who played the affable, beer-loving bar fly Norm on the hit 1980s comedy Cheers, has died aged 76.

title.children: Cheers star George Wendt dies aged 76

image.altText: Ben Roberts-Smith in a suit and tie

props.synopsis: The Victoria Cross recipient's appeal, which was heard in February last year, was unanimously thrown out by the full bench of the Federal Court on Friday.

title.children: Court finds Ben Roberts-Smith 'brazen' in defamation appeal rationale

image.altText: Four young models pose in black outfits in front of a brick wall

props.synopsis: After the shock departure of New York based IMG from Australian Fashion Week last year, the annual industry event is tailoring things to better suit the local industry. But not everyone is happy about it.

title.children: Australian Fashion Week has new owners, and it's becoming more exclusive

image.altText: CFA members holding signs outside parliament

props.synopsis: Victorian councils say they do not have the resources to collect or enforce a new tax which has sparked protests in Melbourne and the regions.

title.children: Councils join forces to oppose Victoria's emergency services levy

image.altText: Three men in suits shaking hands and holding blue reports in their hands.

props.synopsis: The freshly announced commission of inquiry into child safety will be the third such government funded investigation since 2003. So what's going to be different this time around?

title.children: Queensland's child safety system is like watching a horror movie on repeat

image.altText: A 1930s Sepia photo of six men in civilian clothes standing on the deck of a ship.

props.synopsis: When one side of the Spanish Civil War asked the world for help, a small band of Australian men and women answered the call.

title.children: Australia told these people not to go to war. They went anyway

image.altText: A Carlton captain hands over the ball to a club great wearing a suit, as both men shake hands after a game.

props.synopsis: Twenty years ago today, suburban VFL/AFL men's footy in Melbourne came to an end. On the anniversary of Carlton vs Melbourne at Princes Park, we talk to Anthony Koutoufides and others, looking back at the memories from suburban grounds, and how the game has changed.

title.children: 'It was hard to accept': The day the AFL said goodbye to suburban footy

image.altText: a childs hand and mothers hands playing with lego blocks

props.synopsis: The NSW government is investing millions into family preservation services to reduce crisis management and keep kids out of foster homes. A mother explains how it worked for her family.

title.children: Family preservation or child protection? For Tara, the answer is clear

image.altText: Jay Vine cycles through the streets of Italy

props.synopsis: A trio of Australians reach the top 10 in the 10th stage of the Giro d'Italia, but none are as quick as Dutch winner Daan Hoole.

title.children: Untimely puncture thwarts Aussie Vine in Giro d'Italia's 10th stage

image.altText: Multiple packets of colourful pharmaceutical medicines.

props.synopsis: Subsidised training for pharmacists so they can treat more conditions has been announced by the Tasmanian government, but not all agree with the plan.

title.children: Pharmacist to be able to treat more conditions under state budget measure

image.altText: A painting depicting crowds and a fire in a French city square.

props.synopsis: The next time you pick up a bag of spuds from the supermarket or fill up the car with petrol, you can thank a treaty signed in 1875 for the metric system that underpins daily life.

title.children: 150 years ago, 17 countries signed a treaty that affects how we live today
